content.text: Describe the motion of the cyclist from time \(= 6.0s\) to time \(= 10.0s\)
Determine the distance moved by the cyclist from time \(= 6.0s\) to time \(= 10.0s\)
distance = .........m
Fig. 1.1 shows the speed–time graph for a cyclist at the beginning of a race
Determine how many seconds there are in 1 minute and 29 seconds
number of seconds = .........s
Calculate the average speed of this cyclist
average speed = .........m/s
Another cyclist travels \(1000 \text{m}\) in 1 minute and 29 seconds
Calculate the resultant horizontal force acting on the cyclist
resultant horizontal force = .........N
direction =
Describe the effect of the resultant horizontal force in (c)(i) on the motion of the cyclist
The horizontal forces acting on a cyclist vary
Fig. 1.2 shows the horizontal forces at one moment during a race
The spring is made from wire
Describe how to determine the diameter of the wire accurately
You may include a diagram as part of your answer
Using Fig. 2.2, determine the extension of the spring with a load of 4.0 N
extension = .........\(cm\)
The length of the spring without a load is 8.0 cm
Calculate the length of the spring with a load of 4.0 N
A student adds loads to the spring. She measures the extension for each load
Fig. 2.2 shows the graph of extension against load for the spring
A teacher uses a spring in a demonstration
The spring is shown in Fig. 2.1
A boy weighs 620 N
Calculate the mass of the boy
mass of boy = .........\(kg\)
Fig. 3.1 shows another boy sitting on a solid block of wood
The total weight of the boy and the block is 1200 N
The area of the block of wood in contact with the ground is \(0.16 \text{m}^2\)
Calculate the pressure exerted on the ground
State the principle of conservation of energy
The type of energy stored in the battery is ................................... energy
The type of energy stored in the stop-watch's second hand is ................................ energy
The stop-watch has a bell
When the bell rings, energy is transferred to the surroundings as ................................ energy
Fig. 4.1 shows a stop-watch that is powered by a battery. The stop-watch measures a time period in minutes and seconds
Complete the sentences about energy transfers in the stop-watch that is measuring a time period
Complete Table 5.1 by writing the correct temperature for each definition

table.html:
definitiontemperature/°C
pure water boiling at standard atmospheric pressure
pure ice melting at standard atmospheric pressure
the lowest possible temperature of matter

content.text: The temperature of air in a room is \(15^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Calculate the temperature of the air in kelvin
temperature = .........K
Table 5.1 defines three specific temperatures
State the name of the process for thermal energy transfer through the metal rods
The rods are made from different metals. The rods have the same length and diameter. The ends of the rods in the Bunsen flame are at the same temperature
State how the demonstration shows which metal transfers thermal energy at the greatest rate
A teacher demonstrates thermal energy transfer through some metal rods. Fig. 5.1 shows the arrangement
The metal rods are placed on a block of wood
The demonstration compares how quickly thermal energy is transferred to the wax at the end of each rod
A playground includes a concrete area with white and black squares, as shown in Fig. 5.2

The Sun shines on the concrete area during the day. The temperature of the concrete area increases. During the afternoon, students compare the temperature of the white squares with the temperature of the black squares
State and explain whether the white squares or the black squares have the higher temperature. Include the name of the process of thermal energy transfer from the Sun to the squares
When a wave travels on the surface of the water in the ripple tank, the water particles vibrate at right angles to the direction of travel of the wave
State the term for a wave in which particles vibrate at right angles to the direction of travel
Complete the sentence about the wave property shown in Fig. 6.1
The change of direction of the wave is called ............................................
Fig. 6.1 shows that the direction of the wave changes as the wave enters the shallow water
State why the wave changes direction
The speed of the wave in the deep water is \(35 \text{cm / s}\)
Determine the frequency of the wave. Use the information in Fig. 6.1
frequency = .........\(Hz\)
The teacher demonstrates waves moving from deep water into shallow water
Fig. 6.1 shows the crests of the waves, viewed from above. The arrows show the direction of wave travel
wave crests
deep water
A teacher uses a ripple tank to demonstrate the properties of waves
Table 7.1 lists three uses of electromagnetic (e.m.) waves
Complete Table 7.1 by adding a suitable type of electromagnetic wave for each use

table.html:
usetype of e.m. wave
electric grills
to treat cancer
to detect fake bank notes

content.text: State the type of electromagnetic (e.m.) wave used for the satellite television signal
The geostationary satellite is in orbit
Describe the orbit of a geostationary satellite used for satellite television signals
State the source of the energy that powers the solar cells
State how energy is transferred from the solar cells for use by the satellite
The arrows on Fig. 7.1 show the path of satellite television (TV) signals travelling from a transmitter to a receiver
The student switches on **one** lamp
State which switches the student closes to switch on only **one** lamp
The student opens all the switches then switches on **two** lamps
State which switches the student closes to switch on **two** lamps
A student connects a circuit with two lamps and three switches, \(\mathsf{S}_1\) , \(\mathsf{S}_2\) and \(\mathsf{S}_3\) , as shown in Fig. 8.1
Fig. 8.2 shows the manufacturer's information for one of the lamps
Calculate the resistance of the lamp when it is connected to a \(6.0 \text{V}\) power source
resistance = .........\(\Omega\)
Calculate the electrical power transferred in the lamp when it is connected to a \(6.0 \text{V}\) power source
Include the unit
power transferred = .........unit
Fig. 9.1 shows a magnet spinning steadily near to a coil. There is a reading on the voltmeter
Explain why there is a reading on the voltmeter
A step-down transformer reduces the mains voltage of \(220\mathrm{V}\) a.c. to \(12\mathrm{V}\) a.c
The transformer has 5000 turns on the primary coil
Calculate the number of turns on the secondary coil
number of turns = .........
State how a neutral atom becomes a positive ion
State the type of nuclear emission which is the most ionising
Isotopes of copper (Cu) include: Cu - 63 and Cu - 65
Explain what is meant by 'isotopes of copper'
A teacher provides the data in Table 10.1 about the decay of a radioactive sample
Use the information in Table 10.1 to determine the half-life of the radioactive sample
Describe how to store radioactive materials safely
State the name of the force that keeps the Moon in orbit around the Earth
State the time taken by the Moon to complete one orbit of the Earth. Include the unit
time for one orbit = .........unit .........
A device on the Moon sends a radio signal to the Earth
The distance from the Moon to the Earth is \(3.8 \times 10^{8} \text{m}\)
The speed of a radio wave is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the time the radio signal takes to travel from the Moon to the Earth
Fig. 11.1 shows the Moon orbiting the Earth
An astronomer observes light from a distant galaxy
She writes this conclusion:
‘The observed wavelength of light from the distant galaxy is longer than the wavelength of the light emitted by the galaxy.’
Explain how this conclusion supports the Big Bang Theory of the Universe
